entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French estuffes goods, from estuffer to fill in (with rubble), furnish, equip, of Germanic origin; akin to Old High German stopfōn to stop up, from Vulgar Latin *stuppare stop

def.dt: :materials, supplies, or equipment used in various activities: as
:military baggage
:personal property
:material to be manufactured, wrought, or used in construction clear half-inch pine stuff Emily Holt
:a finished textile suitable for clothing
:wool or worsted material
:literary or artistic production
:writing, discourse, talk, or ideas of little value :trash
:an unspecified material substance or aggregate of matter volcanic rock is curious stuff
:something (as a drug or food) consumed or introduced into the body by humans
:a matter to be considered the truth was heady stuff long-term policy stuff
:a group or scattering of miscellaneous objects or articles pick that stuff up off the floor
:nonphysical unspecified material conservation and … all kinds of good stuff Eric Korn
:fundamental material :substance the stuff of greatness
:subject matter a teacher who knows her stuff
:special knowledge or capability showing their stuff
:spin imparted to a thrown or hit ball to make it curve or change course
:the movement of a baseball pitch out of its apparent line of flight :the liveliness of a pitch greatest pitcher of my time … had tremendous stuff Ted Williams
:dunk shot
:to fill by packing things in :cram the boy stuffed his pockets with candy
:to fill to satiety :surfeit stuffed themselves with turkey
:to prepare (meat or vegetables) by filling or lining with a stuffing
:to fill (as a cushion) with a soft material
:to fill out the skin of (an animal) for mounting
:to fill by intellectual effort stuffing their heads with facts
:to pack full of something immaterial a book stuffed with information
:to fill or block up (as nasal passages)
:to cause to enter or fill :thrust stuffed a lot of clothing into a laundry bag
:to put (as a ball or puck) into a goal forcefully from close range

dt.un: used in the imperative to express contempt if they didn't like it, stuff 'em Eric Clapton
often used in the phrases stuff it and get stuffed

def.dt: :to stop (a ballcarrier) abruptly in a football game stuffed the runner just short of a first down
:someone or something unusually good
:something befitting or appropriate only to children
:something extremely simple or easy
:small rope (as spun yarn or marline) usually identified by the number of threads or yarns which it contains

entry.et: Middle English strouten, from Old English strūtian to stand out stiffly, struggle; akin to Middle High German strozzen to be swollen

def.dt: :to become turgid :swell
:to walk with a proud gait
:to walk with a pompous and affected air
:to parade (as clothes) with a show of pride
:to display one's best work :show off
